70704584.review:
Besides BF1942, Day of Defeat is one of the best class-based WWII shooter. It has a perfect balance between tactics, teamplay and all out shooting.

This game is straight forward and is an excellent online FPS game.
The player control of the models and guns is tight - extremely tight. It feels seamless between one's choice of movement and the actual gameplay. In this sense you feel in complete control, and thus the behaviour of your players feels like a true extention of oneself.
The game lends itself well to teamplay with excellent voice over microphone. The sound in the game is very good, and listening is a critical part of playing well.

The Day of Defeat community is extensive and skilled and has produced an enormous amount of modified material. There are tons and tons of player that created custom maps which are equal in quality to the core of 20 stock maps which come with the game.

Even though this game came out a long time ago, there's still a lot of active servers worldwide.The skill level of the player base is fairly high, but DoD players are usually well-helpful to new players.
If you like running and gunning in a WW2 environment, you gotta give this game a try. You can also play it offline by installing free bots to learn with.

66791545.review:
The Good
-Great nostalgia trip for those who played back in the day. All the original sounds and visuals are intact. Will really bring back some great memories and you'll have fun doing so. 
-Select users and servers are real gems. Some good people left playing the game are very welcoming.
-Cheap. For $5 can't really go wrong.

The Bad
-Online community is on life support. Few servers available and those that are are filled with 75% bots
-The human players you do come across are crotchety old men who like to blather and complain
-Grenades are way overpowered and you'll find yourself exploding for no reason
-Too many servers use crappy custom maps filled with garbage addons and mods. Would be great to play more stock maps for the nostalgia.

Buy this game if: You used to play Day of Defeat back in the day and are feeling nostalgic. It's a lot of fun for $5, and your rose-tinted glasses may be enough to overlook the game's faults.

Don't buy this game if: You've never played it before and/or you're looking for a new experience. It won't be worth it. There are so many objectively better games out there that this game can't hold a candle to.

65903191.review:
Day of Defeat is a multiplayer first-person shooter that simulates squad-level infantry combat between the adversaries of World War II's European Theatre; the Allies and the Axis powers. Players can choose to join either the Allied or Axis armies, with the Allies include the United States or Great Britain and the Axis include Germany.

A round begins with two opposing teams starting simultaneously in their respective spawn area of a map, both acting towards the goal of achieving their respective objectives whilst preventing the enemy team from accomplishing theirs.[2] A round ends when one team accomplishes all of its objectives, with that team claiming victory. Eventually, the game with the expiration of a set time limit, and the team with the most objectives achieved is the winning team regardless of kills or casualties, except in the case of both teams having not achieved any objectives or having achieved the same number of objectives.

Weaponry in the game attempts to realistically portray those that would be found in World War II, and the gameplay reflects this aesthetic choice. Recoil can be heavy and the game doesn't allow the player to fire while running or jumping.[2][3] The game also features a stamina bar, preventing the player from sprinting for long periods of time and forcing them to actively conserve energy.[2]

63693966.review:
"Days of Defeat" may be one of the most outdated releases in the Valve catalog, and it isn't very hard to see why with the many glaring issues it presents.

I went into this game optimistic, this is because more often than not, old multiplayer-based Valve titles fail to live up to the standards of today. These games may have helped to set them, but the double-edged sword is that they are the very basic forms of what is available to us now, therefore making them pretty much useless for anyone besides avid fans to come back and experience. Unlike single-player games of the same era, although games have evolved on that front as well, there are many factors that make those experiences unique and worth coping with outdated controls and graphics in order to witness a good or even great game in its original state. With a title such as "Day of Defeat", your only option is to play solely multiplayer, and you have to rely on other people being active on servers you want to play on, otherwise there really is no experience left for the player to take advantage of. Since time only moves forward, eventually this game will lose all value solely based on the fact it will lose its entire base, and in turn, be mostly forgotten. This is expected of a multiplayer experience, but this game has failed to make an impact in the same way many other multiplayer games have, and those games usually have a single-player experience that tags along to give a timelessness to the game, unlike "Days of Defeat".

A main problem with this game I don't see with something such as "Team Fortress Classic" is that I struggle to see the value of playing this game even at the time it was released. There are things about it I do appreciate and enjoy, such as the premise, style, and design, but ultimately the bad and frustrating issues outweigh the good by a baffling margin. A huge problem is the player base itself, those who have either mastered the game or figured the best way to oust fair players are the only ones really playing this game nowadays, not new players that dilute the waters to create a more balanced experience for all who wish to give this game a shot. The shooting is rather basic as well, this was released before mainstream implementation of aiming down sights, and since there are many players camouflaged and well versed in the game's strengths and weaknesses, it makes it that much harder to get into this game as a newer player. The maps here seem more simplistic and unpolished than in other games of the same time, making traversing them and attempting to best the enemy team a boring and difficult affair in the worst way possible. You'll be luckier than most if you are able to hone your skills and restrain from giving up on this relic of the past like many have before.

"Day of Defeat" is one of those very forgettable games that no one really mentions when you talk about Valve and their more than impressive line-up of releases. At least with a fair amount of these sorts of titles, I can see the value that they held when they came out and that they aren't up to today's standards based solely on the fact that they set those standards decades ago, but "Days of Defeat" feels like an outlier that really was just an alternative to the truly excellent games the industry was releasing at the time, not a main attraction.

[RATING: 4.6/10]

59855159.review:
This game might be old but it still has people online that are friendly welcoming and fun to play with, and the mechanics are still fun.

GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS: 
dod is not your traditional classic ww2 shooter either, each side has there own period apropriate weapons, and each weapon has its own feel, like persay you enjoy playing the class with the tommy gun then the next game you get put on the other team and you go for that sides equivlent to the tommy gun but surprise! Its nothing like the tommy gun though it might be fully automatic like the tommy but the kick is different and the general feel of the gun is much different and it makes for a very fun experiance when playing.

SOUND DESIGN:
This game has some amazing sound design not only for the weapons but also the world around you!
for starters after you play this game for a couple of hours and get to play as both sides you can start to hear the difference in american weaponry and german weaponry. You can be pushing forward to the enemy and then you hear gunshots not only can you hear where its coming from but it might sound a little like the american weapons that you might be using but theres a certian crack or deeper tone that you can hear and it can help you figure out if its enemy or a friend. Then you have the foot steps they are the same for both you and the enemy but the advatage would be your mini map, its your best friend in sneaky combat situations your friends have a circle with a pointer pointing to where there look at, and if you hear footsteps extremely near by and you look up at your mini map and you don't see any friendlies around then you better get ready to fight! Now for the ambience, it can be very imersive to be sitting inside of a building antisipating some one to enter and not only do you hear the combat nearby which sounds amazing but you will also hear distant combat in some of the maps and there is also artilary fire in a certain area which really adds to the atmosphere. I really love the sound design for this game!

MAP DESIGN:
I really love the maps for this game it is open to all of the classes that you are able to play it has sniper posts, spots for mgs then its got cover in the best areas and even cover that if it is taken advantage of correctly it can make that spot quite op both sides of the maps are always equally balanced the maps also have areas where you can place charges and blow out a wall or a door to allow for an advantage or it could be your downfall ,and it makes for some very fun and imersive maps.

56261698.review:
It's a shooter unique for a few reasons.
1) The community has been playing for 20 years.  Servers are full of very polite older gamers who have warm conversations.  If you play late (3-4 am) you'll play against finely tuned bots.
2) The maps are complicated, destructible and morph as you play.
3) Camoflauge and use of terrain is very important.
4) Team HUD map.
5) Movement/Accuracy tradeoff.
6) Sound of players, and how you control the sound you let off is very important.

I've never had firefights as difficult or prolonged, or such a high skill ceiling in any other game.

54585643.review:
Day of Defeat is one of Valve's classic MP games in the GoldSrc engine. Set in World War II, you can play as either Allied or Axis soldiers, with objective based maps, not unlike Counter-Strike. Of course, there's no hostage rescue or the like here; the objectives are capturing control points across the map, or defending them from the enemy.

There are different classes you can choose, each with their own weapons, and they even differ between factions, with each one getting historically accurate weapons. Or at least it seems that way, as I'm by no means an expert in WWII.

While I haven't played much, I enjoyed the little I played; which was mostly in the map based on the Normandy landings. Storming that beach was really fun, even in the old graphics of GoldSrc. It's a shame Day of Defeat: Source didn't get an official version of that map.

Overall, it's an enjoyable MP game.

50873241.review:
Honestly, is something like this even needed anymore?

PROS: The game still has that classic FPS feel.  You can still feel all the inspiration the game pulled from the Half Life engine to help it run.  The sounds, backgrounds, and overall play is complete here.

CONS:  The game does feel very dated, and can be a little difficult to get the feel of the movement.  Everything is a little stiff.  On top of that, the community is all but dead for this game.

FINAL: The question posed above really does hang over the game as a whole.  Day of Defeat has been completed outdated with the release of Day of Defeat: Source, giving little reason to come back to this.  Due to that, and the mostly dead community, I really can't recommend this game.

50852100.review: Not bad for a project that started out in a college dorm. Had massive fun playing this game back in my youth. The sound of bullets whizzing past your ear or slamming into some nearby surface was disturbingly realistic. Getting into a game was incredibly easy, and the action draws you in like a real war movie. Once you went online, the adrenaline rush is unsurpassed. The sense of satisfaction you felt in taking a crucial victory location or taking out four enemies in a row simply couldn't be beat. This game started the World War online FPS genre. Valve is horrible at making new games which is a shame. They were ahead of the curve and lost because they refused to produce any new games under the Day of Defeat franchise.

47961238.review:
Back in highschool 2006 i started playing this game on steam.
It was second FPS game what i ever got on my steam account back in the days.
What do i have to say about this game you may ask, well..
It's one of the best WW2 games out there, despite of Call of duty 1 & 2, this game had it all.
Main focus on capturing flags, not as a spawn point, but as conquering the whole map and winning the game.
I really put time on this game since it was only my second shooter what i had that time.
I used to play Counter-Strike but this game put Source Engine to the new level.
Controls are nice, gunplay is good and it was one of the first games where you could go prone if you wanted.
I miss these games where every loadout in different maps are different, like how in avalanche US has M1 Garand, M1 Carbine, M1A1 Thompson, Springfield, BAR, 30. Cal LMG, Bazooka etc And Axis has MP40, STG44, MG42, MG34, Kar98K with scope/ironsight, G43 semiauto rifle, Panzershrek.
In some maps you have instead of STG44 you have option to pick FG42 and sometimes even more different weaponloadout which is nice.

Sides what you can play as are US, British or Germany.
I think there might be mods for Soviets too.

Maps were nice, original maps like Avalance were my favorite, also the wintermaps were awesome.

I get goosebumps from the sound of artillery or when a grenade explodes in water, MG42's sound haunts me to this day.

TLDR; One of the best WWII games out there, littlebit arcady, easy to learn hard to master.
ps, don't blink, if you blink, you dead.

40888463.review:
This is a very hard game to review. 

Mainly because I feel most people are expecting a comparison between this and its successor- day of defeat:source. I love both of these games to death, but the similarities are few and far between. Obviously source has better graphics, but the maps and communities are nearly polar opposites. 

Day of Defeat is much harder than its Source counterpart. Mainly because of the source engine itself. DoD has a very weird sense of physics. So weird in fact, it's hard to explain. Your weapons are widely inaccurate when you're moving in nearly any form (which is expected) but the time it takes to stop moving is hard to get used to. Jumping feels right, sprinting feels good, but they're both limited by a short energy bar. I have no problem with this whatsoever- it makes sense to me that they'd put a lot of realism into that. 

The gunplay is, for lack of a better word, nice. The guns aren't pretty by any stretch, but this is an old game, stop complaining about it. They aren't hard to handle like Counter Strike, but they feel real. Killing an enemy takes a lot of effort, but gunfights are ended quickly because of how damn powerful your weapons are. In a military shooter like this one, that feeling is essential. I don't wanna feel like I'm walking around weilding nothing more powerful than a squirt gun with hot sauce in it.

The popularity of this game has sparadically decreased since its release, but thats expected. Whereas most people have moved on to Source, there's still very much a community that thrives here. Most of them for the nostalgia, but a good part of them have joined because they're looking for something new. Veterans here are very common (not war veterans, guys.) and you could tell that this was a piece of their childhood. I'm being serious. Some of these guys joined steam way back when it was made. Are they good at the game? Oh my god. I'm lucky that I walked out of spawn sometimes.

What's my personal verdict?
I feel like this is a relic. Something everybody should experience at some point in time. That's not that ridiculous- especially considering this game is so cheap off-sale anyway. It's hard to get the hang of, but damn do you ever feel good afterwards. Sadly, though, at the end of the day I do prefer the Source version. I hold both of these close to my heart as milestones of my slow transition into PC gaming.

38219957.review:
Alright, I was going to write a review for the newer, version of this game, Day of Defeat: Source first, but having played this game more than that, I thought I'd spit out my thoughts on this one first.
So, for a regular 21st century gamer for me, who plays the newer games like CS:GO, GTA V and Rocket League (which have good graphics arguably), will soon find this game unbearable for our eyes. It looks horrible on todays standards, and I could not recommend this game for anyone that doesn't want to get a huge breath of old dusty air on their faces. Playing this game is like getting a 200 years old book thrown at you.
However, not everything about this game is bad. The community is still fairly large, meaning that you can most likely maybe possibly find a server with human beings in it. This is mostly because of the 30 to 40 year-old dads who play this game because they used to back when we were small and still playing at the sandbox.
Please, if you have gotten this far, don't take this review personal. This is my view on the game, that probably once was a great WW-game. The Source version just happens to be better. I don't really like the Source version too much either, but at least it has a huge lot better graphics than this one.
However, don't get scared. If you like old stuff, you've found it. The old men playing this game will help you get the hang of it. Or own you.
4/10, because even if it once was a good game, it surely is not by todays standards.
